title-group.article-title: Book Review: Early childhood matters: Evidence from the effective pre-school and primary education project

contrib.aff: Belle Wallace, Director: TASC International, UK, ISBN 978-0-415-48243-1 264 pps

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue: New technologies and virtual learning
article-meta.product: SilvaKathyMelhuishEdwardSammonsPamSiraj-BlatchfordIramTaggartBrenda (eds), Early childhood matters: Evidence from the effective pre-school and primary education project, Routledge Publishers (2010)

body.p: Early Childhood Matters traces the rapid development of early years education, from the 1990s up to the present time. It provides details of a project called the Effective Pre-school and Primary Education (EPPE) project, which has influenced national policy and practice, making a significant difference to children’s social and intellectual development. The book highlights the importance of the interaction of home and school environments on the progress of young children.

list-item.p: provides new evidence of the importance of the influence of early childhood;
shows how early experiences affect children’s cognitive, social and behavioural development;
gives guidance with regard to educational policy and young child care; and
examines how the influences of home and school interact to shape educational outcomes.

body.p: The editors are both very experienced and expert in the field of early childhood education, and hence they bring deep insight and understanding into the text, making it a vital reference book for all parents, carers, and early years educators. The EPPE project is the first large-scale, longitudinal study to conclusively show not only that pre-school education provides children with a better foundation for more formal schooling, but also that these early years experiences form a lasting influence on children’s lives, especially those children from socially disadvantaged backgrounds.

The effect of this early years research led to the UK government’s determination to establish quality pre-school education for all children, resulting in the creation of 3000 children’s centres and centres for parents who are the child’s first educators.

The high commitment of the research team and the rigour and mixed methodology of the actual research, together with its wide scope, detail and reliability, has resulted in a book that will be of supreme importance to policy makers, researchers, teachers and parents for many years to come.
The detailed case study evidence, [shows] that effective pedagogy in high quality settings is able to balance adult initiated and child-led activities, that cognitive and social development are complementary, and that children learn best through ‘sustained shared thinking’. (Foreword: Gillian Pugh)
I recommend this book to everyone concerned with early years education.
